1493614537869860871.text: The first traffic light, a two-light “stop/go” signal had been developed in London. But Morgan improved on the design, adding the third signal – yellow – to the light to reduce traffic congestion patterns and accidents. Today, it’s everywhere. https://t.co/wFGLDMb4wV

1493614536078897161.text: Morgan personally risked his life to help save the trapped men, rescuing eight. National newspapers reported on the rescue, but neglected to mention his role. He wrote to the mayor, “I am not a well-educated man; however, I have a Ph.D. from the school of hard knocks.”

1493614534484967440.text: He became known as “the inventor of Harlem Avenue,” where he lived. In 1916, a group of miners were buried in a tunnel collapse under Lake Erie. The Cleveland Police called Morgan, who rushed – still in his pajamas – with masks and volunteers down to the tunnel.

1493614532543062018.text: His love of creating pushed him to experiment, leading to his prototype of a breathing device which would serve as the early blueprint of the gas masks used in WWI. It sold poorly, until he hired a white man to pretend to be the inventor in a demonstration. Then it took off.

1493614530886348808.text: Morgan started as a sewing machine repairmen. The process of taking apart and rebuilding the machines fascinated him, and he tinkered with how to improve their production quality. He started his first business with his wife, and became a community leader in Cleveland.

1493614527556067342.text: Garrett Morgan was a Black inventor and businessman. He became particularly known for safety products, including the modern day three-color American traffic light and an early gas mask, but also had a line of beauty products for Black hair. #BlackHistoryMonth https://t.co/AgU9X0NHHW

1492856159774167046.text: She said, "I believe we hold in our hands the power once again to shape not only our own but the nation's future—a future that is based on developing an agenda that radically challenges limitations in our economic development, educational achievement, and political empowerment.”

1492856157836398593.text: For her powerful accomplishments in the struggle for justice, Height received the Citizens Medal Award, the Congressional Gold Medal, and the President Medal of Freedom. https://t.co/EyhLQiTdWu

1492856155911208962.text: As one of the “Big Six” civil rights organizers, she was a key player in the Civil Rights Movement. She was often ignored in the press due to her gender, but behind the scenes she led the way, advising activists and presidents like Eisenhower, and LBJ.

1492856152874373120.text: As an active member of @dstinc1913, she organized college students and served as the sorority’s 10th National President for nearly a decade. Shortly thereafter, she became President of the National Council of Negro Women, a position she would hold for 40 years.

1492856149829378056.text: She began to work with the National Council of Negro Women, which she would later lead. Its founder, Mary McLeod Bethune, told her, “The freedom gates are half ajar. 'We must pry them fully open.”

1492856146243248128.text: She earned a degree as a social worker, and continued her activism. She worked with day laborers in New York, Black women who were picked up from street corners and exploited as domestic workers.

1492856143726661635.text: Her political activism roots back to her high school days, where she became vocal among anti-lynching campaigns. As the only Black participant in a national oratory competition, she earned first place and a college scholarship.

1492856140534800384.text: Today, she is “widely credited as the first person in the modern civil rights era to treat the problems of equality for women and equality for African-Americans as a seamless whole.” https://t.co/oAY12xfbgU

1491845545501114370.text: During his time in office, he led investigations into the KKK and other criminals. He was also active on the Board of Education, and after his term ended he served as Florida Superintendent of Public Instruction and as a Tallahassee City Councilman.

1491845544095977479.text: Though he unsuccessfully ran for a seat in the Florida House of Representatives, he was appointed Secretary of State under Gov. Harrison Reed. The position was seen as ceremonial. He made it proactive.

1491845542611230721.text: He became more involved in politics. He was one of eighteen African American delegates to the 1868 Florida Constitutional Convention.

1491845541013114882.text: After the war Gibbs felt called to move south to help newly freed slaves. Eventually, he arrived in Florida in 1867 and started a private school in Jacksonville.

1491845539478048768.text: He became a prominent abolitionist, working with Frederick Douglass and others, writing for anti-slavery publications, and serving as Pastor for the First African Presbyterian Church in Philadelphia. He called for equal treatment on the rail cars and accommodations.

1491845538001608708.text: Born in Philadelphia in 1821, Gibbs worked as a carpenter’s apprentice before he attended Dartmouth College, the third Black man to do so. He later attended Princeton Theological Seminary to become a minister.

1491845535724154881.text: Jonathan Clarkson Gibbs was a pastor, abolitionist, and Florida’s first and only Black Secretary of State. Tragically, Jesse Brown died on that mountain, leaving behind a wife and two year old. But today he is remembered as a hero.
 
Said his friend Roland Christensen, "A man's greatness is not measured by the years he's had here but the way he lived his life." #BlackHistoryMonth

1489958074580361220.text:
In an act of immense courage, flightmate Tom Hudner intentionally crash landed his own plane to get to his fellow pilot.
 
"If it wasn't Jesse down there, I don't know if I'd have taken the chance I did," he said. "Jesse would have done the same thing."
https://t.co/rR3bICzYgI

1489958072265199619.text: Brown became the Navy's first Black pilot. Then, on 4 December 1950, Brown was part of a search and destroy mission in Korea when his plane was damaged. He crashed, pinned beneath his aircraft in sub-zero weather. His flightmates assumed he had been killed, then saw him waving.

1489958069744377859.text:
One trainer, Roland Christensen, befriended the lone Black recruit and volunteered to teach him. They remained friends long after.
 
"I'm trying to get accepted into this place here," Brown wrote in one letter to Christensen after a transfer. "I guess that I shall, finally."

1489958068196675594.text: He tried to join the school's aviation program, but was denied. Then, he learned of an available Navy program, and enlisted. He wanted to fly.

1489958066569293836.text: Following in the footsteps of his childhood hero, Olympic gold medalist Jesse Owens, he attended Ohio State University, paying his way with jobs as a waiter, janitor, store clerk, dry cleaner, and boxcar loader, working until midnight but maintaining top grades.

1489958064644149248.text: His father took him to an air show at age six. As a paperboy, he read in the newspaper about pioneering Black aviators. He wrote to the White House to ask that Black Americans be allowed to fly. He'd look up from working in fields and say, "I'm going to fly one of those one day."

1489958061745872901.text: “Always courageous,” U.S. Navy pilot Jesse LeRoy Brown was the U.S. Navy's first Black pilot, and the first Black naval officer killed in the Korean War. His heroism in service to our country earned him the Distinguished Flying Cross. #BlackHistoryMonth https://t.co/c08stWHgYs

1488519470662434826.text: Today, Black women still account for less than 3% of U.S. doctors. We still have more to do. But 150 years ago Dr. Rebecca Lee Crumpler blazed a trail to follow.

1488519468129169413.text: She was buried in an unmarked grave. But today, she is rightly recognized as one of the mothers of American medicine.

1488519465855856643.text: Dr. Crumpler treated women and children regardless of their ability to pay, and published the groundbreaking "A Book of Medical Discourses," on women’s health. https://t.co/BOxRWkcItZ

1488519463502766081.text: She moved to Virginia and found “the proper field for real missionary work," caring for "the least of these" by helping the Freedman’s Bureau assist over four million formerly-enslaved Americans make the transition to a free life.

1488519461120487428.text: Rebecca entered medical school around the outbreak of the civil war, and graduated to become the only Black woman out of America's 54,543 known doctors. It's likely that during her life she never knew that she was America's first Black female doctor. https://t.co/euCoJmAdhC.

1488519457639182344.text: Dr. Rebecca Lee Crumpler was the first Black woman in America to earn a degree as a medical doctor. Hospitals and pharmacies shunned her, but she persevered, bringing critical medical knowledge to poor communities. Here's her story. #BlackHistoryMonth https://t.co/I5C67lH7qM

1485704019167395845.text: More market competition means stronger supply chains, better prices for families, and more support for farmers and ranchers. I will continue to work with Floridian farmers, ranchers, grocery stores, and workers to ensure that families can get what we need.

1485704017657630720.text: It’s simple: corporate monopolies have caused prices to jump and shelves to stay empty. It’s good for businesses to make a profit. But they should have to compete in a fair marketplace, where they invest those profits back into their workers, supply chains, and businesses.

1485704016281718791.text: Meanwhile, corporate profiteers have taken advantage of the excuse to raise prices—not because they need to, or because they have a better product, but simply because they can. It’s wrong. They are making record profits while working families struggle.

1485704015098925069.text: When there is no competition, it means that one disruption causes a hole. Factory fire? Cyberattack? Severe weather? COVID-19? There’s no one else to step up.

1485704013828009984.text: The evidence is clear: big corporations have squeezed independent stores and food producers out of the marketplace, leaving us with a fragile food system. When one thing goes wrong, it causes catastrophic effects.

1485704012536102912.text: I grew up the daughter of a maid and janitor and it was critical for my family to have access to affordable food. We grew vegetables in the garden, traded with neighbors, and relied on our local grocery stores.

1485704011135258628.text: Today corporate profits are spiking while Floridians pay more at the store and family farmers go under. Corporate consolidation has caused supply chain issues and price spikes. This issue is critical to Florida families.

1485688143013679108.text: Nearly a year ago, I cosponsored the bipartisan TRUST in Congress Act to ban members of Congress from trading stocks. Congressmembers should not be able to profit from our work to create laws for the people. The American people support our bill.

1479487361092395010.text: Poitier continued to dominate at the box office and take home awards and nominations. In Guess Who's Coming to Dinner, he played a man in an interracial relationship, something that was still illegal in 17 states until just six months before the film's release.

1479487359100108805.text: As @MarkHarrisNYC wrote, Poitier "was well aware that...his win would be used to sell a preposterous falsehood...that the movie industry had solved its race problem." Wrote Poitier, "I knew we hadn't 'overcome' because I was still the only one."

1479487357183221764.text: He won his Best Actor Academy Award in 1963 for Lilies of the Field, an inspiring moment for millions of people. It was, and remains, a stunning accomplishment. But it was not the end of the struggle.

1479487354997985283.text: In 1959 and 1961, he starred in A Raisin in the Sun, the first Broadway play written by a Black woman (Lorraine Hansberry) and first with a Black director (Lloyd Richards). The story, depicting Black life, "changed American theater forever."

1479487352993161218.text: In 1958, he became the first Black actor nominated for the Best Actor Academy Award, for his role in The Defiant Ones. He was also nominated for a Golden Globe, and won awards in Britain and Berlin the same year.

1479487350484918285.text: Sidney Poitier was a legend and inspiration. 1461525960461799430.text: I have personally appealed to House, Senate, and administration leaders and made it clear that Floridians cannot continue to suffer and die due to lack of affordable health care. I will keep fighting for passage through the Senate. #BuildBackBetter

1461525957349720067.text: #BuildBackBetter will give Medicare new powers to negotiate down the cost of prescription drugs and add new out of pocket caps for prescription drugs (including $35 insulin), saving Floridians thousands of dollars.

1461525956099776515.text: #BuildBackBetter will significantly reduce health care costs, including reducing your premium by up to $800 per year, give Medicare the power to cover hearing for the first time ever, and cover hundreds of thousands of Floridians for the first time.

- Less taxes. One of the largest tax cuts for working Americans ever.
- Lower costs. Health care, home care, college. Close the Medicaid gap.

1427407647507161088.text: I will use my position as a member of both the Homeland Security and Intelligence Committees to make sure our national security personnel have the resources and support they need to handle any emerging threat and protect our homeland.

1427407646705991681.text: As the situation on the ground develops, it is imperative that our country remain vigilant of potential threats.

1427407645879767047.text: Our immediate priority must be ensuring the safety and security of our troops, diplomats, aid workers, and the many Afghans who served with us. They were instrumental in supporting America and our allies, and we need to do everything we can for them.

1427407645091274755.text: In 2017, I traveled to Afghanistan to meet with our troops, hear their stories, and deliver to them every Floridian’s appreciation for their bravery and sacrifices. We’ve asked so much of our troops and their families, and today, I’m holding them close to my heart.

1427407643635818496.text: For two decades, America’s armed forces — the greatest fighting force the world has ever known — served bravely and selflessly in Afghanistan.

1366218427271176195.text:
One physician, Zabdiel Boylston, believed Onesimus. The death rate among his patients was 2.2%. The death rate among others was 14.3%.
 
For many years, history credited Boylston with bringing inoculation to America. Today, we know the truth.

1366218426491019270.text:
In 1921, Boston experienced a severe outbreak.
 
This was the time to test Onesimus' technique. But the white residents of Boston resisted.

1366218425631203329.text: Before its eradication in 1980 (a scientific and medical miracle), Smallpox was a blight on humanity, killing 500 million people in the last 100 years of its existence alone, and scarring and blinding survivors.

1366218424553254912.text:
In 1716, he taught Americans something he had learned in Africa: that a small, controlled infection of smallpox could protect from future serious disease. This "inoculation" was the precursor of vaccines.
 
It was practiced in China, the Middle East, and Africa, but not Europe.

1366218423102033921.text:
In the late 1600s or early 1700s, a man was enslaved and brought to Boston. He was renamed Onesimus, meaning "useful, helpful, or profitable." We do not know his real name.
 
He would become one of the most important figures in American public health. #BlackHistoryMonth
